introduction.p: Work has a different meaning in physics than it has in everyday life. In physics we say that a force has done work on an object if it has caused the object to move. We quantify the amount of work through a well-defined mathematical procedure to be described below.
The fundamental definition of work relies on Calculus, but work by a constant force can be defined without the need of Calculus. We will see both ways below.

subsection.title: Work by a Constant Force

sidebyside.p: Suppose you pull on a suitcase with a constant force \vec F at all instants of an interval that begins at t_i and ends at t_f. During this time, the suitcase has a displacement \vec r_{if} as shown in . Other forces also may be acting on the suitcase, but here, we want work by this force alone.

subsection.p:
Then, work by the constant force \vec F, to be denoted by W_{if}, equals the product of the component of the force parallel to the displacement and the magnitude of displacement.
W_{if} = F_\parallel\, r_{if},

sidebyside.p:
where F_\parallel is projection of force vector \vec F on the direction of the displacement vector \vec r_{if}. You may recall that this is just F\cos\theta.
F_\parallel = F \cos\theta.

subsection.p:
That is, work of a constant force will be
W_{if} = F\, r_{if} \cos\,\theta.
Actually, a more succinct way of stating this is by way of dot product of vectors \vec F and \vec r_{if}. Thus, the following dot product gives work done by a constant force \vec F.
W_{if} = \vec F \cdot \vec r_{if}.

From the product of force and displacment, we find that the unit of work will be \text{N.m}. Now, if we expand this into base units we find that work can be written in various equivalent units, including the unit of energy.
\text{N.m} = \frac{\text{kg.m}}{\text{s}^2}.\text{m} = \text{kg}.\left(\text{m}/\text{s} \right)^2 = \text{J}.
That is \text{N.m} is same as unit of kinetic energy, i.e., Joule. Just because the unit of work is same as the unit of energy, work is not energy. We will show by work-energy theorem below that work is amount of energy that gets transfered between bodies that interact via a force between them. When we study thermodynamics, we will encounter another mechanism by which energy is transferred between bodies - that mechanism will be called heat.

example.title: Work of a Constant Force Pulling on a Suitcase at an Angle

statement.p: A suitcase is pulled by a tension force of magnitude 40\text{ N} in a strap acting at angle 30^\circ above the horizontal direction as shown in . Other forces on the suitcase are gravity, normal force, and rolling friction. As a result of these forces, the suitcase moves a distance of 20\text{ m}. What is the work done on the suitcase by the tension force?

solution.p:
The situation gives us all the quantities needed to compute the force by the tension force.
W_{if} = F_T\, \Delta r\, \cos\theta = 40\times 20\times\cos\,30^\circ = 693\text{ N.m}.

example.title: Different Work by the Same Force but Acting at Different Angles

statement.p: A boy pulls a 5 \text{-kg} cart with a 20 \text{ N} force at an angle of 30^{\circ} with the horizon for some time. Over this time the cart moves a distance of 12 \text{ m} on a horizontal floor.
(a) Find the work done on the cart by the boy.
(b) What will be the work done by the boy if he pulled with the same force horizontally instead of at an angle 30^{\circ} with the horizon over the same distance?

solution.title: a
solution.p:
We use the definitition of work with angle \theta = 30^\circ.
W = 20 \text{ N} \times 12 \text{ m} \times \cos\, 30^\circ = 208\text{ N.m}.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
Now, the angle is \theta=0, which means \cos\, \theta=1. This gives
W = 20 \text{ N} \times 12 \text{ m} \times 1 = 240\text{ N.m}.
More work is done now. Is this a waste of work? No, as you will see by work-energy theorem that cart in (b) be going faster in the end than in (a).

example.title: Moving a Crate on a Rough Surface on Different Paths to Same Destination

sidebyside.p: Workers want to move a crate of mass 200 kg from a site on the ground floor to a third floor apartment. They know that they can either use the elevator first, then slide it on the third floor to the apartment or first slide the crate to another location marked C in the figure, take another elevator to the third floor, and then slide it on the third floor a shorter distance.

statement.p: The trouble is that the third floor is very rough compared to the ground floor. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the crate and the ground floor is 0.1 and between the crate and the third floor surface is 0.3.

Find work needed by the workers for each path, i.e., for ABCDE and for AFE paths. Assume that the force workers need to do is just enough to slide the crate at constant velocity at zero acceleration. Note: The work by the elevator against the force of gravity is not done by the workers.

solution.title: Setting up
solution.p:
The workers will need to apply a horizontal force equal in magnitude to the kinetic friction force. Since acceleration is assumed to be zero, the balancing of forces on the crate gives us the following for the magnitude of the kinetic friction force.
F_k = \mu_k\, m \, g.
That means the force by workers has this magnitude also. Let us denote this by F.
F = \mu_k\, m \, g.
Since the force by the workers is in the same direction as the displacements, the work by them for a displacement \Delta r is
W = F \Delta r = \mu_k\, m \, g\, \Delta r.
Now, we use this expression on each path, making sure to use the appropriate \mu_k and \Delta r. Since mg is common factor, we can just work out the number for this once.
mg = 200\times 9.81 = 1962 \text{ N}.

solution.title: AFE
solution.p:
(Path AFE)
Therefore, we will get the following for the work on path AFE.
W_\text{AFE} = \amp W_\text{AF} + W_\text{FE} \amp = 0 + 0.3\times 1962\times 30 = 17,660 \text{ N.m}.

solution.title: ABCDE
solution.p:
(Path ABCDE) On path ABCDE we will get the following work.
W_\text{ABCDE} = \amp W_\text{AB} + W_\text{BC} + W_\text{CD} + W_\text{DE} \amp = 0.1\times 1962\times 30 + 0.1\times 1962\times 10 + 0 + 0.3\times 1962\times 10 \amp = 13,730 \text{ N.m}.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Fundamental Definition of Work
subsection.p: To define work by any force, not just work by a constant force, we need to use Calculus. Once again, we want work by a force \vec F during an interval t_i to t_f . Suppose the body follows the path shown in the , under the influence of this force as well as other forces, not shown.

sidebyside.p:
To define work by force \vec F we first divide the full path into small straight segments. Then, we define the work on each segment by a dot product between the force vector and the displacement of that segment. For instance, we obtain the following work \delta W on the segment \Delta \vec r in the figure.
\delta W = \vec F\, \cdot\, \Delta \vec r,
which is obviously F_{\parallel} |\Delta \vec r|.

subsection.p:
Summing \delta W's over the entire path gives us the total work W_{if} during the interval from t_i to t_f . When the segments become infinitesimally small we write the sum as a line integral , which we decorate with \text{path} to indicate that the value may depend on the path taken between positions \vec r_i and \vec r_f.
W_{if} = \int_{\text{path}}\, \vec F\, \cdot\, d\vec r.
The integral is an example of a line integral, sometimes also called the work integral. This integral needs to be evaluated over the path given by the position vector \vec r at times in the interval t_i to t_f. These integrals require further processing before you can actually come to regular integral(s) that you would do to get the value. See the exercises below.

example.title: (Calculus) Work Integral for a Path on Axis

statement.p: Suppose we have a force, \vec F = - 20\, x\, \hat i + 10\, \hat j, which is in units of \text{N} when x is in \text{m}. What is the work done by this force for a motion on the x axis, on a direct path from x = 2\text{ m} to x = 5\text{ m}?

solution.p:
First, we notice that the infinitesimal displacement vector, d\vec r = \hat i\, dx + \hat j\, dy + \hat k\, dz on the path is simply along the x axis.
d\vec r = \hat i\, dx,
obtained by simply setting dy = 0 and dz = 0. Therefore, the dot product on the path takes a simple form as well.
\vec F\cdot d\vec r = -20\, x \, dx.
This is now restricted on the path, and we can do the integral over the variable x as a regular integral.
\int_{\text{path}}\,\vec F\cdot d\vec r = \int_2^5\, -20\, x \, dx = -10\left( 5^2-2^2\right) = -210\text{ N.m},
where I have put the unit of work in the last step.

example.title: Work by Area Under F_x vs x

statement.p:
For simplicity, let path of motion be along x axis from x=x_i to x=x_f with no turn around in the path. Then, work will be only by F_x (x_f - x_i), where F_xm> is x component of the force. In this simple setting, work in Eq. can also be evaluated by area under the ciurve.
\text{Work } = \text{ Area under }F_x\text{ versus }x.
An example of this calculation is illustrated in . During the displacement from x=0 to x=40\text{ m}, work done is positive, +500\text{ N.m}, and during displacement from x=40\text{ m}to x=60\text{ m}, work done is negative, -300\text{ N.m}. The net work will be 200\text{ N.m}.

figure.caption: Work by area-under-the-curve method for a motion on x axis that does not have a turn around in the motion on the axis.

statement.p: Now, if you have a turn around in the motion, e.g., a ball that is shot up and returns back, you should be careful and find work for each direction separately. illustrates an example of a motion that has a turnaround on x-axis; for comparing purposes, this is same as up to x=40\text{ m}, but then, the force as well as displacement turns around. During the displacement from x=0 to x=40\text{ m}, work done is positive, +500\text{ N.m}, and during displacement from x=40\text{ m}to x=20\text{ m}, work done is, again, positive, +300\text{ N.m}. The net work will now be 800\text{ N.m}.

figure.caption: Work by area-under-the-curve method for a motion on x axis that has a turn around in the motion on the axis.

example.title: (Calculus) Work Integral for a Two Dimensional Case

statement.p: A friction force acts opposite to the displacement direction and depends on the location. Suppose a kinetic friction force of magnitude, F = 10\, x\, y^2, acts on the box when the box is at the coordinates (x,y). The unit of the force in \text{N} when x and y are in \text{m}.

sidebyside.p: We want to compare work done by this force on two paths between A and C: A-B-C versus A-C direct. Let the coordinates of these points be (x_A, y_A) = (0, 2\text{ m}), (x_B, y_B) = (5\text{ m}, 2\text{ m}), and (x_C, y_C) = (5\text{ m}, 3\text{ m}).

statement.p: (a) Find work done by F on the path A-to-B-to-C.
(b) Find work done on by F the direct path A-to-C.
(c) On which path is the absolute value of work by F greater?

solution.title: a
solution.p:
We can break up the calculation into two parts: (i) A-to-B and (ii) B-to-C. We do this because the path descriptions of these two segments are different.
\amp \text{On AB we have } y = 2, \amp \text{On BC we have } x = 5.
The force and displacement vectors on these paths are:
\text{On AB:}\amp \amp d\vec r = \hat i\, dx, \amp \vec F = -\left( 10\, x\, y^2\right)_{y=2}\,\hat i = -40\,x\,\hat i .
\text{On BC:}\amp \amp d\vec r = \hat j\, dy, \amp \vec F = -\left( 10\, x\, y^2 \right)_{x=5}\hat j = -50\,y^2\,\hat j.
Therefore, we have the following integral on the path AB.
W_{AB} = \int_0^5\, -40\,x\, dx = -500\text{ N.m},
and on path BC
W_{BC} = \int_2^3\, -50\,y^2\, dy = -\dfrac{50}{3} \left(3^3 - 2^3\right) = -317\text{ N.m}.
Adding the two we get the total work on A-B-C path.
W_{ABC} = W_{AB} + W_{BC} = - 817\text{ N.m}.

solution.title: (b) and (c)
solution.p:
(b) On path AC, x and y are related by
y = mx + b,
with
m = \dfrac{3-2}{5-0} = 0.2,\ \ b = 2.
That is,
y = 0.2\, x + 2.
This can be used to eliminate y and dy from equations below.

We use the unit vector for the direction from A to C to write the force vector in an analytic form. This unit vector is
\hat u = \dfrac{ (5-0)\hat i + (3-2)\hat j}{ \sqrt{(5-0)^2 + (3-2)^2}} = \dfrac{5}{\sqrt{26}}\, \hat i + \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{26}}\, \hat j.
Since kinetic friction is pointed in the opposite direction to the displacement, we get the following analytic expression for the force vector, since the magnitude 10\, x\, y^2 is positive.
\vec F \amp = -10\, x\, y^2\, \hat u \amp = -10\, x\, y^2 \left( \dfrac{5}{\sqrt{26}}\, \hat i + \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{26}}\, \hat j \right).
The force and displacement vectors on this path are:
\amp d\vec r = \hat i\, dx + \hat j\, dy = (\hat i\, + 0.2\, \hat j)\, dx, \amp \vec F = -10\, x\, (0.2x + 2)^2 \left( \dfrac{5}{\sqrt{26}}\, \hat i + \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{26}}\, \hat j \right),
where I used dy = 0.2 dx on this path so that we can write the work integral as an integral over dx.
W_{AC} = \int_{AC}\, \vec F\cdot d\vec r = \int_{0}^5\, \left( \text{ something here }\right) dx.
The dot product is ugly to work out. You can do that on a separate piece of paper. I found the following.
W_{AC} = - \dfrac{52}{\sqrt{26}}\, \int_0^5\left(0.04\,x^3 + 0.8\, x^2 + 4\, x \right)dx = -914\text{ N.m}.

(c) Clearly, we get
\left| W_{AC} \right| \gt \left| W_{ABC} \right|.
This says that it would cost less energy to go on path A-B-C than to go directly.

exercise.title: Calculating Work by Force of Gravity

statement.p: A baseball of mass 0.3 \text{ kg} is lobbed vertically up. It reaches a height of 20.0\text{ m}.
(a) How much work does the weight of the ball do on the way up?
(b) How much work does the weight of the ball do on the way down?

solution.title: a
solution.p: To compute the work, we need magnitudes of force and displacement vectors, and angle between them.

sidebyside.p:
\amp F = mg = 0.3\times 9.81 = 2.943\text{ N}, \amp r_{if} = h = 20.0\text{ m}, \amp\theta = 180^{\circ}.
Now, we just multiply them together to obtain work,
W_{if} = 2.943 \times 20.0 \times \cos\, 180^{\circ} = -59\text{ N.m}.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
We do not need to do an entirely new calculation here. We just need to notice that the angle between force and displacement now will be 0 ^{\circ} rather than 180^{\circ}. That would make work positive.
W_{if} = +59\text{ N.m}.

exercise.title: Calculating Work of Gravity when No Change in Height

statement.p: A baseball of mass 0.3 \text{ kg} is lobbed at 45^{\circ} above the horizontal. It reaches some height on its parabolic path and returns before it is caught at the same height as it was launched from at a horizontal distance of 40 \text{ m}. Find the work done by the force of weight during the flight.

hint.p: Work by weight on way up is negative and work on way down in positive.

solution.p: As shown in , the work when the ball is going up will be negative and equal amount of positive work will be done when the ball is in its way down. The sum of the two works will be zero.

exercise.title: Work by Spring Force - Work by Area-Under-the-Curve

p.p: A block attached to a spring is moving on a horizontal surface along x axis. The x component of the spring force is given by F_x = -k\, x, where k is the spring constant and x is the x coordinate of the block.

statement.p: What is the work done by the spring force when the block's position has moved from x=x_i to x=x_f? The plot of F_x versus x is given in figure.

hint.p: Use area under the curve. (triangle + rectangle)

solution.p: We need to find the shaded area in the figure. The area is made up of a triangle and a rectangle.

md.mrow: W \amp = \dfrac{1}{2}\left( -kx_f + k x_i \right) \left(x_f - x_i \right) + k x_i\left( x_f - x_i\right),

exercise.title: (Calculus) Hockey Puck on a Rough Surface with Varying Friction

statement.p: A hockey puck of mass 300\text{ grams} is shot across a rough floor with the roughness different at different places, which can be described by a position-dependent coefficient of kinetic friction. For a puck moving along the x-axis, the coefficient of kinetic friction is the following function of x, \mu(x) = 0.1 + 0.05\,x, where x is in meter.
Find work done by the kinetic frictional force on the hockey puck when it has moved (a) from x = 0 to x = 2\text{ m}, and (b) from x = 2\text{ m} to x = 4\text{ m}.

hint.p: Use F_k(x) = \mu_k(x) F_N and integrate \int F_k(x) dx .

sidebyside.p:
From the vertical direction of the free-body diagram of the puck, we have N = mg. This gives the following for the kinetic friction force.
F_k = \mu_k\, N = \mu_k(x) m g.
Since \vec F_k is in the opposite direction of the displacement, we get the followinf for the work integtral.

solution.p:
W_{if} \amp = -\int_{x_i}^{x_f} F_k(x) dx = -mg\int_{x_i}^{x_f} (0.1 + 0.05\, x) dx, \amp = -mg( 0.1\, x_f - 0.1\, x_i + 0.025\, x_f^2 - 0.025\, x_i^2).
We now use the values of x_i and x_f to find the values of W_{iuf}.

(a) Here x_i=0 and x_f=2. Therefore,
W_{if} = -0.3\times 9.81 ( 0.1\times 2 + 0.025 \times 2^2 ) = -0.883\text{ N.m}.

(b) Here x_i=2 and x_f=4. Therefore,
W_{if} \amp = -0.3\times 9.81 ( 0.1\times 4 - 0.1\times 2 \amp \ \ \ \ + 0.025 \times 4^2 - 0.025 \times 2^2 ) = -1.47\text{ N.m}.
